text: Para makasiguro na 100% from pure coconut water ang suka nyo, better make one yourself.    ==================================================== How to Make Vinegar from Coconut Water  Materials:      3 liters coconut water     1/4 tsp. yeast     2-1/4 cups white sugar     1 liter mother vinegar(starter)  Procedure:      Collect coconut water and strain through a clean cheesecloth.     Dissolve the sugar in coconut water.     Pasteurize the mixture for 20 minutes at 65 ¬∞C.     Cool and transfer the mixture into sterilized gallons or containers.     Add yeast. Cover tightly and allow to ferment for 4-7 days.     Slowly decant the alcoholic mixture and heat further for 20 minutes at 65 ¬∞C.       Add the starter and set aside undisturbed for a month or until maximum acidity is attained.
author: Deriuzky Hernandizk

author: Pol Gonzales

text: With due respect, perhaps experts in the field of toxicology should be the ones weighing in.  According to this document online, https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/acetic-acid  It doesn't differ much if vinegar is made through biogenic or non biogenic means as far as acetic acid is concerned.  It seems what really matters is the concentration of acetic acid and whether the process of vinegar production also produces toxic by products.
author: Paul Farol

text: I believe the issue here is not whether synthetic acetic acid could be safely ingested by humans or not, rather the misrepresentation of this sour product as vinegar. that is the point of contention. if the toxicologists say it is okey to consume synthetic acetic-acid based sour condiment, the choice should be left to the consumers. but to pass it off as vinegar, which by FDA standards is a sour substance produced through a natural fermentation process using natural products, is a violation of the law.
author: MannyPi√±ol

text: I saw and read a number of discussions in other documents online.   Among them is one focusing on Monsanto which uses acetic acid produced thru non fermentation process.  Still, I would contend,  the real issue here is;  1. Acetic acid concentration 2. The level of concentration which is proven to be toxic 3. The presence  and levels of concentration as well as toxicity of other chemicals produced even through natural processes, i.e., methanol  Web results Formic acid, acetic acid and methanol: their relevance to the verification of the authenticity ... PDFhttps://www.unige.ch ‚Ä∫ ArchivesSciences
author: Paul Farol

text: Paul Farol may requirement ang batas kung anong uri ng suka ang dapat ibenta sa merkado tapos ipinipilit mo parin kung ano dapat pagtalunan sa isyu na yan?
author: Jojo Cruz

text: People should read this scientific paper so they get more information and won't panic.  It's not acetic acid whether it's natural or synthetic that makes vinegar harmful.  It's the concentration and the possible contaminants such as formaldehyde and formic acid and methanol that makes it toxic. FDA should clarify that there is no proven harmful effects of using synthetic acetic acid to allay people's fear. And they should make sure that naturally fermented acetic acid does not contain high concentrations of contaminants.
author: Polo Prez

text: With all due respect Mr. MannyPi√±ol I beg to disagree, that the basic issue here is the lawful definition of vinegar.  The people won't panic or fret about it if it's just a matter of bureucratic definitions.  It's the health effects of synthetic vs natural acetic acid.  Don't you see why they are asking which brands use synthetic acetic acid.  They don't care if these companies abide by the BFAD rule.  For all they know they have been buying vinegar from untested, unlicenced market vendors.  The DA should have addressed any unfounded health effects and toxicity of using diluted acetic acid which is the main component of ANY and ALL vinegars in the world.  That will allay the fear of the populace and put an end to the debate then the lawful definition is secondary. That's what's missing in this announcement and the point you're missing in your argument above.
author: Polo Prez

text: Jojo Cruz unang una, hindi ako nakikipag talo sa kalihim natin kaya huwag mong i-frame nang ganyan.  Pangalawa, nakita ko kasi na unti unting lumilihis sa unang punto ng usapan... from food safety (which is a major concern) to whether something should be labeled as vinegar or non vinegar.  Natuwa ako nung una, pero ngayon parang nagtataka at medyo nababahala sa naiisip ko.  But I'll insist on thinking the best of our Agriculture secretary.

text: We are selling naturally fermented vinegar from sugar cane, traditionally fermented in earthen jars called burnay by us Ilocanos pero d kami makasabay sa kamurahan ng presyo ng Datu Puti, Silver Swan, Rose or any other commercial brands na kung talagang sanay kang gumagamit ng puro ay alam mo. From the comments ng mga nagtatanong sa brand ng kung anong ang synthetic ay obviously gumagamit nito kaya cla nababahala kung synthetic ang nabibili nila. Our product often has what uneducated users of natural vinegar as latak but the misconception as it is ay dahil meron cyang sedimentation dahil sapal un from the sugar cane. Iniisip ng iba matapang masyado pag Sukang iloko pero d nila alam lalabas na mas mura pa cya dahil konti lng magagamit. And lastly, natural vinegar doesnt Expire! If what you are buying ay me expiration ibig sabihin pagtagal tubig na lng cya. Ang pambahay namin ay mga sukang fermented ng 3-5 years na. It doesnt expire, it gets concentrated but suprisingly mellows pa na parang wine. Buy Local!
